conclusion: Understanding the problem involves analyzing a velocity-time graph for a skydiver to determine acceleration direction during the first 10 seconds.
The graph shows velocity in m/s on the y-axis and time in seconds on the x-axis, with labeled points at 10 seconds (20 m/s) and 15 seconds (10 m/s).
The slope of a velocity-time graph gives acceleration; positive slope means positive acceleration, negative slope means negative acceleration.
From 0 to 10 seconds, velocity increases from 0 m/s to 20 m/s, with the curve concave up, indicating a decreasing rate of velocity increase.
Since velocity is increasing, acceleration is in the same direction as velocity. The skydiver moves downward, typically considered negative.
In physics, downward is usually negative and upward positive for vertical motion. Increasing downward velocity means negative acceleration.
If velocity is negative and increasing in magnitude, acceleration is negative, indicating downward direction.
People may confuse increasing velocity with positive acceleration, but in downward motion, increasing negative velocity means negative acceleration.
Initially, gravity causes downward acceleration; air resistance builds up, opposing motion, reducing net downward acceleration.
During 0 to 10 seconds, gravity dominates, causing downward acceleration; air resistance increases, reducing net acceleration.
After 10 seconds, velocity decreases, indicating air resistance stronger than gravity, causing net upward acceleration.
Velocity levels off at around 10 m/s, likely terminal velocity where gravity and air resistance balance.
During 0 to 10 seconds, increasing downward velocity means downward acceleration, despite slowing rate due to air resistance.
Direction of acceleration during 0 to 10 seconds is downward.
Considering calculus, velocity is the derivative of position, and acceleration is the derivative of velocity.
From t=0 to t=10 s, velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s; slope (acceleration) is positive in the downward direction.
Clarifying sign convention: downward is negative, so increase in negative velocity indicates greater downward acceleration.
